conclusion: The force F must not exceed the maximum static friction force between A and B, which is 1 N, to keep them stationary.
Static friction prevents A from sliding relative to B when F is applied.
Consider the kinetic friction force between B and the ground.
The kinetic friction force is calculated using F_k = μ_k * N.
The normal force N is the weight of both blocks: (1 kg + 2 kg) * 10 m/s² = 30 N.
The kinetic friction force between B and the ground is F_k = 0.1 * 30 N = 3 N.
Since the kinetic friction force is greater than the static friction force, F must not exceed 1 N.
